comment.author: 22918055@N02
comment._content: This images is looking east from 42nd Street and 7th Avenue.  The building shown on teh left in teh center is the Times Building.  In the distance you see the platform for the Elevated on Sixth Avenue.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: great catch.. Now can you get the name of the theater?  Hammerstein's something or another.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: Hammerstein's Roof Garden, operated by Oscar Hammerstein I. He opened it in 1904, above two theaters that he owned: the Victoria and the Republic. Jack Johnson, the African-American world champion prizefighter, appeared at the Victoria Theater in July of 1910, for an engagement of several days.

comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: Thanks!  Johnson was a key figure, maybe even a tragic figure, in the history of rase relations in America.

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content:
The New York Times, on July 12, 1910, ran a story about Johnson's tumultuous welcome in New York City. (This was right after his victory in Reno over former heavyweight champion James Jeffries, "The Great White Hope," cemented Johnson's claim to the title):
[http://query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9E07E6D9173AE733A25751C1A9619C946196D6CF

comment.author: 35072786@N08
comment._content: Thanks Wystan and Shadrach Christopoulos for the additional information on boxer Jack Johnson and his appearance in New York City. We will add some to the description when we update the database.
